fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Invariant subspace
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Definition 5.2
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 7.1.1

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. Let L\in \mathcal {L}(V) be a linear operator on V. We call a subspace U\subseteq V Invariant under L if for each u\in U we have L(u)\in U.
That is to say, the image of every vector in U under L remains in U. So L(U)\subseteq U.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Eigenvalues and eigenvectors
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Definitions 5.5 and 5.8
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 7.1.1

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. Let L\colon V\to V be a linear operator on V. Then \lambda \in \mathbb {F} is an Eigenvalue of L if there is a non-zero vector u\in V such that L(u)=\lambda u. The vector u is called an Eigenvector of L corresponding to eigenvalue \lambda .
Compare this to the notion in elementary linear algebra.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. Let L\colon V\to V be a linear operator on V. Then \lambda \in \mathbb {F} be an eigenvalue of L. Then we define the Eigenspace of L to be V_{\lambda }=\{v\in V\mid L(v)=\lambda v\}

fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 5.11

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let V be a Finite-Dimensional Vector Space over \mathbb {F}. Let L\colon V\to V be a linear operator. We say L is Diagonalizable if the eigenvectors of M(L) form a basis of V. In this case, M(L)=\begin {pmatrix}\lambda _{1} & & & \\ & \lambda _{2} & & \\ & & \ddots & \\ & & & \lambda _{n}\end {pmatrix}

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Existence of eigenvalues
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 5.19
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 7.4.1

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let V\neq \{0\} be a Finite-Dimensional Vector Space over \mathbb {C}. Let L\colon V\to V be a linear operator. Then L has at least one eigenvalue.

Let n=\dim (V), let v\in V be a nonzero vector. We have the collection of vectors \{V, Tv, T^{2}v, …, T^{n}v\} Since this contains n+1 vectors, it must be linearly dependent. Then there exists scalars a_{0},a_{1},…,a_{n}\in \mathbb {C} not all zero, such that 0=a_{0}v+a_{1}Lv+a_{2}L^{2}v+…+a_{n}L^{n}v Let m be the largest index such that a_{m}
eq 0 (so all a_{k}=0 for k>m and we can just drop these terms). Since v
eq 0, we must have m>0 (and even possibly m=n). Consider the polynomial p(z)=a_{0}+a_{1}z+…+a_{m}z^{m}. Then using the immediate consequences of the fundamental theorem of algebra, we can factorize p(z) as p(z)=c(z-\lambda _{1})(…)(z-\lambda _{m}) where c,\lambda _{1},…,\lambda _{m}\in \mathbb {C} and c
eq 0.

Then 0=a_{0}v+a_{1}Lv+a_{2}L^{2}v+…+a_{n}L^{n}v=p(L)v and 0=p(L)v=c(L-\lambda _{1}I)(…)(L-\lambda _{m}I)v which means at least one of the factors L-\lambda _{j}I must be non-injective. This means \lambda _{j} must be an eigenvalue of L.
Furthermore, if a_{i,i}=0, then we call \mathbf {A} Strictly Upper Triangular.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a field, let X\in \mathop {\mathrm {Mat}}\nolimits _{n}(\mathbb {F}) be an n\times n matrix, let V=\mathbb {F}^{n} be a free vector space over \mathbb {F}. We can decompose V=V_{1}\oplus …\oplus V_{m} where each V_{i} is an Invariant subspace under X and the dimension \dim (V_{1})=\deg (m_{X}(x)) is the degree of the minimal polynomial of X and \dim (V_{i})\leq \dim (V_{i+1}).

Moreover, there is a basis (e_{1},…,e_{n}) of V such that the first \dim (V_{1}) span V_{1}, then first \dim (V_{1}\oplus V_{2}) span V_{1}\oplus V_{2}, and so on; and X with respect to this basis may be written in block form as X = \begin {pmatrix} C_{f_{1}} & 0 & … & 0\\ 0 & C_{f_{2}} & … & 0\\ \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\ 0 & 0 & … & C_{f_{m}}\end {pmatrix} where C_{f_{1}} is the Companion Matrix of the minimal polynomial f_{1} of X, and C_{f_{2}}, …, C_{f_{m}} are the companion matrices of monic polynomials f_{2}, …, f_{m} which are called the Invariant Factors. Moreover f_{j+1}(x)\mathrel {\bigm |} f_{j}(x) for each j=1,…,m-1.
Let G be a Group and X be a set. Suppose G acts on X. Let Y\subseteq X. We say Y is an Invariant Subset of X if G\cdot Y\subseteq Y, i.e., for each y\in Y and g\in G we have g\cdot y\in Y.
If there is some ambiguity about which group Y is invariant with respect to, we say Y is G-Invariant (or Stable under G or G-Stable).

fr:title.text: Traditional way of teaching abstract algebra

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Traditional way of teaching abstract algebra

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The traditional way we teach undergraduates is by introducing several types of gadgets in abstract algebra in the following order:

html:ol.html:li: Initially, there's some discussion of set theory sufficient for developing algebra. This is "time honored tradition" starting with van der Waerden's book.

When the structure-preserving transformations leave something invariant (e.g., Invariant subspaces in linear algebra), composing such transformations also leaves the thing invariant. This is the guiding intuition of what a "symmetry" is, and the "collection of symmetries" is precisely what a "group" is (originally, they were a "group of symmetries" or a symmetry group).

html:li.html:p: (a) But we also saw how, e.g., square matrices have a neat algebraic structure with matrix addition and matrix multiplication. They act like a "number system". This is precisely what is studied with number ring (or just a Ring). A sufficiently nice ring is a Field.
(b) We can generalize linear algebra to describe "vector spaces over arbitrary rings", and these are modules.

html:ol.html:li: Galois theory is offered as the pinnacle of abstract algebra, connecting group theory to field theory. Honestly, I never understood the excitement behind Galois theory, since the beautiful parts of it are just the representation theory of groups (describing how "the same symmetries appearing in different situations").

fr:mainmatter.html:p: This is just the first 7 chapters of van der Waerden's Modern Algebra, Vol. I. Most textbooks have followed this manner of presentation: Dummit and Foote's Abstract Algebra covers this material in the first 14 chapters; Hungerford's Algebra does this in the first 6 chapters.
